â€œItâ€™s not her fault she was born.â€: A Review of â€˜Breasts and Eggsâ€™ by Mieko Kawakami

12/08/2022

Camila Hernandez reviews 'Breasts and Eggs' by Mieko Kawakami, and sheds light on the novel's examination of gender roles.

Image by Photo by Camila Hernandez

By Emily Warner

â€˜How does a child feel about being born?â€™ is a question that permeates Mieko Kawakamiâ€™s 2008 novelÂ Breasts and Eggs (ä¹³ã¨åµ,Â Chichi to ran), a vast, contrary novel on pregnancy that is infused with antinatalist subtext. On the surface, it is a bold, triptych tale about fertility, cosmetic surgery, and bodily autonomy. Upon further dissection, however, one can find an expansive examination of gender roles andÂ ofÂ the silently oppressive system that hinders women in their everydayÂ lives.Â TheyÂ exist in a perpetual hurricane, occasionally knocked by experiences or conversations shared at their profoundly feminine expense.

In the same yearÂ Breasts and EggsÂ was published, Yuriko Koike, the governor of Tokyo, referred to the gender inequality barrier for women as an â€œiron plateâ€ rather thanÂ simply a â€œglass ceiling.â€ With such underrepresentation in government, womenâ€™s rights in Japan remain an issue with limited advocates for aggressive policy changes.Â Through lyrically shaded interrogations of motherhood, Kawakami broadens the discussion of reproductive rights beyond the conventional pro-choice/pro-life argument to include issues of women's dignity and the problematization of the bio-essentialized maternal drive. Her novel outlines the possibilitiesÂ availableÂ to Japanese women who deviate from the norm, whose sexuality, she notes, is and has always been â€˜extremely controlled.â€™ Locked in a kind of â€˜surveillance society, Kawakami states that â€˜Women [in Japan] have no means of obtaining birth control pills at pharmacies, for example, because the laws concerning reproduction and women's bodies are created by men.â€™

All three central characters ofÂ Breasts and EggsÂ â€“ Natsuko, Makiko, and Midoriko, Makikoâ€™s daughter â€“ are constantly alarmed by their bodies and how they believe they are perceived by others. In the first section of the book, Makiko, originally from the more rural Osaka, visits Natsuko with her daughter in order to look into her breast implant options.Â In her mind, she has the notion of breast implants asÂ a physical and mental representation of femininity she can't quite grasp, despite working as a waitress and being a single mother. AlthoughÂ NatsukoÂ doesn't necessarily agree with her sister's ambition,Â sheÂ doesn't get in the way of her pursuits. A seething atmosphere of ambition and animosity is created over the course of a few days as the personalities of the three ladies collide with their desires for their bodies and minds.

In the second, far longer episode, we meet Natsuko ten years later, looking to publish a bestselling bookÂ whilstÂ simultaneously preoccupied with examining her own relationship with intimacy, sexuality, and reproduction. The novel's experimentation and emphasis on moral issuesÂ isÂ stronger in this section as Natsuko becomes associated with a group of people who were born through sperm donors. Subsequently, she considers her wish for a child and her alternatives for doing so given that she abhors sexual contact. All the while, she continues to doubt her desire for the child she is considering, as well as what it means to wantÂ itÂ in the first place.Â However,Â she is never deterred by the impetus to reach the child she knows will eventually exist.

Japanese politician and writer Shintaro Ishihara scrawled his opinion on Kawakamiâ€™s work as â€˜unpleasant and intolerable;' which is to say Kawakamiâ€™s inclusion of a dialogue surrounding menstrual pads, bodily insecurities and artificial insemination is not palatable to Japanâ€™s more conservative, close-minded authors. The notion of 'punk' (a kind of art that expresses rage against patriarchal, sexist, and capitalist structures that have been accepted for far too long) makes up a large portion of the best modern literature in Japan. In his urban fantasy and surrealist stories, Haruki Murakami is known for featuring male protagonists who are experiencing some sort of displacement or existential crisis. Sayaka Murata, moreover, has been bolder in her outspoken criticism of conventions, structures, and hierarchies.

Following this lineage of Â literary outspokenness, the translated edition ofÂ Breasts and EggsÂ became incredibly popular on an international level. In anÂ interview, Kawakami noted: â€˜The novel was put into theÂ context of a feminist novel outside of Japan. [...] But this book is also a meditation on what it means for a human being to give birth. Itâ€™s about reproductive ethics. We believe as a society that to give birth, to be born is an amazing, wonderful thing. But I wanted to pose a question: who has the right to bring a human to life?â€™ Powerfully, she adds: â€˜If youâ€™re thinking seriously about [the] human experience, you have to think about women. You canâ€™t separate women from the world.â€™

Through this luminous philosophy,Â Breasts and EggsÂ examines the different ethical, practical, and administrative considerations that must be made while determining whether or not to create a new life. It offers a scathing critique of neoliberal biopolitics. Given the advancements in assisted reproductive technologies and the fact that the State has a disproportionate ability to determine who is allowed to have children and who is not, the issues it raises are particularly pertinent today. Our agency will always be entangled with physical and societal difficulties because we are, first and foremost, embodied subjects. Collective experiences like menstruation, beauty rituals, reproduction, and mothering have far too frequently been kept hidden. They are highlighted in Kawakami's masterpiece, which gives voice to bodily sensations and presents a story that is relevant to the entire world in addition to Japan. By doing this, Kawakami questions rigid gender norms, problematicalizes bodily control techniques, and exposes the cruelty ofÂ bodyÂ politics.

This review only scratches the surface of Kawakamiâ€™s deeply intricate work.Â Breasts and EggsÂ neither condemns the decisions made by individuals nor offers any answers to the challenging issues it raises yet it will undoubtedly urge you to confront complex notions of death, love, kinship, identity, and life. Personally, it stuck with me long after I finished reading it and it has become a hallmark of sociological storytelling.

â€˜Happiness can be defined in all kinds of ways, but human beings, consciously or unconsciously, are always pulling for their own version of happiness.â€™
